title: 110_s2006
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" and provides disaster assistance for power transmission and distribution facilities. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act defines a private or investor-owned power facility as a transmission or distribution facility that provides electric or natural gas service to retail customers under State or local jurisdiction, including leased facilities. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act now allows contributions for the repair, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement of private or investor-owned power facilities damaged by a major disaster. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act now permits funding for the repair, restoration, or replacement of private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster. Conditions for assistance to these facilities include defining a "previous major disaster" as one that occurred before the current disaster for which federal aid is being requested. The President may provide funding for repairing, restoring, or replacing private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster, as long as the previous major disaster occurred within 10 years before the current disaster for which federal assistance is sought. The President may provide funding for repairing, restoring, or replacing private or investor-owned power facilities damaged or destroyed by a major disaster, if the costs exceed $2,500 per retail customer and the total costs exceed a certain threshold. The President may provide funding for repairing, restoring, or replacing private or investor-owned power facilities damaged or destroyed by a major disaster if the costs exceed $2,500 per retail customer and the total costs exceed a certain threshold. Additionally, if 25 percent or more of the population in each geographic area of each local government where the facility is located had taxable income below the Federal poverty level in the year preceding the disaster, the owner can apply for funds. A private or investor-owned power facility meeting specific requirements can apply for Federal assistance within 30 days of a major disaster declaration or after contributing $10,000,000 towards repair, restoration, or replacement costs. Private or investor-owned power facilities can request Federal assistance if they are damaged or destroyed by a major disaster. The assistance is limited to costs exceeding $10,000,000 directly incurred by the owner. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act allows for the aggregation of costs from previous major disasters within a 12-month period. The President must approve or disapprove assistance applications within 30 days. The Federal Share for assistance is outlined in Section 406(b)(2) of the Act. The Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities for assistance. The Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act now covers private or investor-owned power facilities for assistance. If it's determined that repairing, restoring, or replacing the facility is not in the public welfare's best interest, the person may opt for a contribution equal to 75% of the Federal estimate's cost. The funds can be used for specified purposes. Private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster may use funds for repairs, construction of new facilities, or hazard mitigation measures as necessary. Private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster are now eligible for funding for repairs, construction of new facilities, or hazard mitigation measures under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security must create regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment to implement the Act and its amendments. The Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment, with Section 3 taking effect immediately.
